comments.commentBody:
Cool! I'd love to see a gallery of their offerings. My husband and I took a cocktails class recently and marveled over a $1,000 Japanese ice ball maker made of solid copper. We settled for a cheap plastic mold in stocking our own bar (pictured here) and just love it. Ice really does help "make" the drink.

Kitt
http://www.kittalog.com
Kitt
All you sourpusses.   It sounds like a grand good time. I would love to have been there.

Witness, really? I've been at this for over a decade, actually 16 years to be totally exact. Many of my Heros and peers have had 20 plus years. This is a transparent competition and he rules are very clear. This event goes all the way to the world level, and is the perfect way to help elevate the craft and art of coffee.
First Mistake: get a site without a kitchen

This a new frontier, all right. Recently there was an TV ad satirizing the notion of imported ice. "Why don't you just freeze imported water?" was the tag line. I dare anyone to taste the difference in a drink due to the shape of the ice, much less the water it was made from. What a scam. I'm tempted to say only in New York, but Chicago, LA, San Fransisco, and London and Berlin won't be far behind. But New York is a drinking town. It should know better.

I don't think tat a 1,000 dollar tax hike on the rich is anything to gripe about. I make less than 30,000 but I give 3,000 to charity every year. The love of money is the root of all evil. Ten % of 30,000 is 3,000 all the way to the top will fix the job.What's funny is all these wealthy people and the dollar only worth 25 cents on the market in the near future. They can use it to start a fire to keep warm. I will keep eating my oodles of noodles and praising The Almighty.

This was a collosal waste of time and money for several reasons, not the least of which is the "OJ Syndrome" that seems to infect jurors in celebrity cases. “We all agreed that he was using steroids,” said Amber Reed, 19, a student from Pinole, Calif. “But the question was did he know he was, and on that we had no proof.”  All the jurors "knew" Bonds was taking steroids and yet they believed Bonds didn't know???  I hope I'm that lucky if the government ever decides to prosecute me.

To poster #272 - I'm not sure who is doing your taxes, but regardless - if you and hubby can't live a very nice lifestyle in Pennsylvania netting $185,000 annually, then there is something very, very wrong with your budget and you need far more financial advice than I can provide you in this post.

Let's face it, the greatest home run hitter of all time is Babe Ruth who hit 60 home runs in fewer games than anyone else. He was a magnificent pitcher but because he was such a great hitter, he was
put into the outfield so that he could bat in every game. Think about it!!

Anybody who saw Barry play over the years knows that he is guilty of using steroids and HGH and that he is guilty of lying.  Plus, this is not a race issue.  Roger Clemens is still battling his way out of a legal quagmire.  McGuire got off and Sammy Sosa, Latino, got off even easier.  Frankly, it's more about personality.  Bond's arrogance is probably the chief cause of all this and it has little to do with his color---or his crimes.  Now we are going to be faced with endless years of controversy about his election to the Hall of Fame.
How can a jury miscarry on the lying charges, but find for obstruction?  Isn't it logical that one is predicated upon the other?

Am I crazy or did Jeter get hurt on opening day a few years ago by sliding into third head first? If so, how could that not be mentioned here? If not, my bad, I didn't bother to google before posting.
"Totally Rigged" so now everyone involved can do it all over again and make more money.

When President Obama was running for election in 2008, I remember reading that a colleague of his in Chicago said there was one thing you must remember about him: often his opponents think they are playing checkers with him when they didn't realize the game was chess. He is always several moves ahead.

It seems as though Obama held his fire while Rep. Paul Ryan got lots of press talking about privatizing and voucherizing Medicare, Medicaid, keeping the tax breaks for zillionaires, etc. Now that Ryan has laid this giant stinking egg of a deficit reduction proposal on the public -- about 98.9 percent of whom are counting on getting Medicare after age 65 -- it's starting to sink in. However, just in case people didn't realize exactly what Ryan and the Republicans want to do to us, I think Obama did a very good job of explaining it today.

I don't hold it against Ryan that he comes from Wisconsin, where another Republican, Gov. Walker, is doing his best to destroy collective bargaining for public servants such as teachers. Unlike Walker, who is undoubtedly a corporate toady, Ryan really seems to be sincere -- he appears to have worked hard on this cruel, slash-and-burn proposal. I think he really believes this would be a good thing for the USA. He actually looked hurt -- almost like he was going to cry -- when he was listening to the president's speech today at George Washington University.

That said, however, Obama spoke harsh truths today, and it's time for the Republicans to act like grownups. No more crying, Boehner, no more biting your lip, Ryan.

To borrow a phrase from the world of poker -- "Shut up and deal."

I'm sensing a pattern here:

April 2008: Philadelphia Address on Race.

April 2009: Cairo University Address.

April 2010: [April address preempted by Health Care signing.]

April 2011: Address on Fiscal Policy.

President Obama Explains It All For You.

It is now confirmed that the judge has declared mistrial on the remaining three counts.

The federal government should take time to rejoice in the single guilty verdict (a victory, no matter how you slice it) and then to proeed with retryinng Bonds for perjury. What the jurors told the press as to how they felt about each evidence/witness as well as what the jurors found missing in proof (something Anderson could have supplied but refused to do) will provide valuable strategic guidance to the prosecutors as they prepare to retry Bonds.

We cannot let perjurors go unpunished. Coverup is worse than the crime. This trial was not about Bonds taking steroids. It was about Bonds lying under oath about taking steroids.

I wish this never happened. But, I also wish the government would issue some statement - so many people did this when the stuff was rampant and the disgrace is manifest - but, can we please stop wasting money chasing these discredited "athletes" and focus the wrath of the the prosecution on the slime who resold the toxic mortgage paper as "investment grade" - put them in jail (instead of awarding them bonus cash) and let's move on.

Bonds' legacy is sealed. It needs to be over.

@Cleve Moffett-post #10--I AGREE with you that steroids have nothing to to with hand/eye coordination. No one saw the ball better than Ted Williams.  However, the strength that steroids provide can easily make, what would be a ground ruled double, into a homerun with just the hard and speedy swing of the bat.  No one can match the record Bonds had in hitting out to McCovey Cove like Barry did in such a short period of time.  Bonds was definitely juiced.  We shall wait and see with Roger Clemens on how quickly and often an aged pitcher can throw a fast ball, so consistently, when his trial comes up.

A bit like the Blagojevich verdict last summer: the jury convicted on what they perceived to be the "least serious" of the charges and hung on the other, more inflammatory ones.

A reaction to prosecutorial "overcharging".

Of course, it doesn't matter much. Five years is five years, regardless the charge.

Santorum has been widely hailed (or derided) as the most intellectually challenged member of the Senate in recent history. Is he running as a counterpoint to Michelle Bachman, who is likewise the most intellectually challenged member of the House? They can run together and write a book about it, "Presidency for Dummies."

Some countries have two paths to refund– one being via enterprises like Global Blue taking their cut, and another "free" system. If you were to visit Norway from overseas, you'd ask the store –any store, not only the ones participating in the tourist business with their "Tax Free Shopping VAT Refund" logos– for a RD-32 form, to be presented at customs before checking in. At Oslo Airport, this procedure may take eight minutes if there's a line, fifty seconds if there is not. You then mail the form to the store, and you're theoretically all set. Each item must cost at least NOK 250, roughly US$45, in order to qualify.
Here's the link (in English) to the Norwegian customs explaining the procedure:
http://www.toll.no/templates_TAD/Article.aspx?id=145097&epslanguage=en
The catch is that coming from overseas you'd hardly think that the prices would be a bargain even without the 25% VAT.

Raising taxes on the wealthy should be a fixed point in any negotiations with Republicans.  They will be fully responsibility for the (significant) pain that will be caused by a default on US sovereign debt if they choose to try to take the debt ceiling hostage.  They will then be duly ushered out of office, as will need to happen if this country is to tackle the challenges that are facing it.

If you want to know the truth lets make the rich tax exempt. Anything to not hear their selfish remarks. The true Americans don't care about a tax break. We work hard for the money and love our Country more than a tax cut. You can always tell the Republicans they only care about three things thats tax cuts,small Government and war. How did GE make a 14 billion profit but not pay any income tax last year? They shift all of their profits off shore and all of their losses in the USA. Bright!!
photo 11 is a simply amazing image - i love the balance and composition, it seems almost like a set-up but actually is a happy coincidence. congratulations, photographer!
Why oh why, would anyone want to "houseclean" these treasures?
